Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Constraints on the Solar Dynamo Using Helioseismology
Award.AbstractNarration: The main research objective of this 5-year CAREER project is to provide new constraints on solar dynamo models, so that a better understanding of the Sun and solar-cycle dynamics becomes possible. Over the course of the project, the PI will focus his research on achieving the stated science objective by completing tasks such as: (i) measuring the meridional and zonal flows at the surface and in the solar convection zone as functions of depth and latitude; (ii) quantifying the time variations of these flows over almost two solar cycles; and, (iii) understanding and correcting the systematics in helioseismic data sets, in part by using numerical simulations. A diverse cohort of graduate and undergraduate students will carry out this research, which will ultimately: (i) produce two PhD graduates in helioseismology; (ii) provide ten minority undergraduates the opportunity to engage in meaningful research experiences; and, (iii) stimulate relevant 6th-grade learning activities about the Sun and high-level content-based professional development training for K-12 instructors. The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Sun is a very dynamic star whose plasma and magnetic fields change on short timescales and decadal timescales. This project studied the Sun's internal "conveyor belt," known as meridional circulation, which is a hidden plasma flow mainly poleward in each hemisphere at the surface, and equatorward below the surface at some unknown depth. This process is a critical component to the magnetic solar cycle and the transport of angular momentum and magnetic fields, but remains poorly understood. This Career project implemented helioseismology, the only tool available to probe the subsurface layers, to study this problem.

The project has many successful outcomes, such as:

  • new measurements of the Sun's meridional circulation in the outer 30 percent of the star that showed multiple cells of flows only measured once before
  • the development of a new technique for helioseismology research to interpret measurements of acoustic waves that utilizes statistical algorithms
  • the publication of 11 refereed articles in prestigious astronomical journals
  • about 2 dozen presentations by project participants, mainly students, at scientific conferences around the world
  • the involvement, mentoring, and financial support of 6 graduate students and 5 undergraduate students, many of whom from underrepresented backgrounds in astronomy
  • three successful PhD dissertations from graduate students involved in the project
  • the publication of an educational helioseismology hands-on software tutorial for beginning students interested in doing research in this field
  • the interaction with dozens of community college and high-school students over the past 7 years in an immersive STEM summer program
  • the PI's development into a critical contributor in solar physics research and his promotion from junior faculty member to full Professor at his institution, as well as the strengthening of the solar physics group there.

The study of the meridional circulation flows in the Sun is now widely viewed as a critical endeavor, as it is inseparable from the understanding of many of the other physical phenomena taking place throughout the Sun. The final answer is still not known despite rigorous work in this project, as it is now widely recognized that unknown systematic effects in helioseismic data are limiting the ability to move forward. The PI and collaborators are turning their attention to resolving some of these effects, so that soon the enigmatic properties of this subsurface conveyor belt can finally be revealed.
